{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3502713,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T14:26:53.159Z","cooked":"

We’ve been using last year’s robot as a testbed for developing new software capabilities (eg vision stuff).

Concurrently we’ve been developing the “ordinary” code (eg, button X does what) on the this year’s robot as it comes together.

We’ve decide to merge the code bases and run the same code on both robots from here on out. To do this the code needs to figure out which robot it is on at initialization time because the robots do have some different characteristics (eg sizes).

Adding to the difficulty is the possibility that any electrical component from the old robot might , in a competition emergency, get moved to the new robot.

What we have so far come to is an “I am testbot” dongle that is plugged into DIO-0 on the testbot.

Just wondering if we missed something obvious, here.

we solved this by differentiating the robots by the RoboRIO serial as seen in our code here

in the past we’ve used the Preferences class, one boolean preference with the key “comp” that we et false on practice bot and true on comp bot. then we apply different configs and such based on that. the only way i see it going wrong is if you have to swap out the rio at comp

I’d recommend distinguishing based on RoboRio:

Check Roborio Serial Number at Compile Time? Programming
I would recommend that you at least explore using the RoboRio web interface “comment” box, the contents of which get stored on the Rio in /etc/machine-info or is accessible from the getComments call. That gives you a no-code-change way to replace a Rio.
","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T14:51:47.794Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":349,"readers_count":348,"score":79.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485278,"topic_slug":"2-robots-1-code","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/check-roborio-serial-number-at-compile-time/474532/15","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Check Roborio Serial Number at Compile Time?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/2-robots-1-code/485278/4","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3502739,"name":"","username":"Wesley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wesley/{size}/155134_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T15:04:50.004Z","cooked":"

If you go this route, make sure you have some way to remind the programming team to update the serial number if you swap the rio at an event. Humans will forget that this is important (if you’re swapping the rio, there’s probably some stress involved), so tape a reminder to the spare rio and/or make “comp bot” the default for unrecognized serial numbers.

The nice thing about using the COMMENTS field (instead of the serial number) is the spare roboRIO for the competition can be prepared beforehand as you work your “packing list” so you don’t have to remember to do something at the competition. My team uses the COMMENTS field.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T15:17:51.170Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":235,"readers_count":234,"score":62.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485278,"topic_slug":"2-robots-1-code","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48578,"username":"Wesley","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wesley/{size}/155134_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/2-robots-1-code/485278/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3502908,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T16:49:17.612Z","cooked":"

We do it based on RIO serial number, we used to do it based on the RIO’s Ethernet MAC address.

The code we are using for that this year is based on Team100s code.

Our implementation for this year can be found here.

github.com

Spectrum3847/2025-Spectrum/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/spectrumLib/Rio.java

package frc.spectrumLib;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Alert;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Alert.AlertType;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotController;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

/*
 * Represents a specific RoboRIO, as a key for configurations.
 *
 * The serial numbers here can be found on the label on the back: add a leading zero.
 *
 * Please keep the ID strings in lexical order.
 *
 * Note that the ID string may change when you reflash the RoboRIO.
 * Based on: https://github.com/Team100/all24/blob/2a109b28467cfddcafb93c7fc85ef60b56a628a2/lib/src/main/java/org/team100/lib/config/Identity.java
 */
This file has been truncated. show original

We did almost the same thing, just used an analog jumper with a resistor divider instead.

One match in 2023, our jumper was missing, and the analog voltage floating into the range of the bench bot, and we sat disabled a whole match.

We switched to the Rio serial number method too. We also though MAC address of the Ethernet port, but the serial number is just easier.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T18:34:08.483Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":24.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485278,"topic_slug":"2-robots-1-code","display_username":"Steven Carmain","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1737,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer/Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/2-robots-1-code/485278/8","custom_user_title":"Programmer/Drive Coach","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503172,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T18:58:29.781Z","cooked":"
Check Roborio Serial Number at Compile Time? Programming
I’d recommend that you have one codebase and switch the constants based on a file you create on the roboRIO.

My usual recommendation is that you:

  • Create a “robot.txt” file on the roboRIO (not via deployment) that contains the robot’s name.
  • If the file is missing or the contents are unrecognized, print a warning/alert and default to the competition robot.
  • Display the robot name at the top of the dashboard,
  • Control variations in hardware configuration using a set of boolean constants.
  • Switch those and other constants based on the robot name.
  • Where you have multiple possible numerical values for a constant, keep them in the same line of code, perhaps using the ternary conditional operator.

We’ve thought about this issue quite hard since the time we sent the robot to an invitational off-season with the wrong codebase and no programmers.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T01:54:12.076Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":62.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485278,"topic_slug":"2-robots-1-code","display_username":"Gavin Matthews","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":4,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/check-roborio-serial-number-at-compile-time/474532/5","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Check Roborio Serial Number at Compile Time?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38743,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)"},"post_url":"/t/2-robots-1-code/485278/9","custom_user_title":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503331,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T20:29:13.760Z","cooked":"

We’ve decided that any hardware that could get swapped from test to comp in the heat of a competition is a big risk. As mentioned above, right now the testbot’s “dongle” tying DIO-1’s signal line to ground is our best idea.

I’m thinking a cooler idea would be for each robot to have something like this Silicon Serial Number Chip on a board riveted to the frame, connected to the SPI (or I2C) connectors.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T20:29:13.760Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":23.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485278,"topic_slug":"2-robots-1-code","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.microchip.com/en-us/product/25aa02e48","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/2-robots-1-code/485278/10","custom_user_title":"Opinions expressed are mine only","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503467,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T22:16:03.199Z","cooked":"
john3928:

I’m thinking a cooler idea would be for each robot to have something like this Silicon Serial Number Chip on a board riveted to the frame, connected to the SPI (or I2C) connectors.

This is the right way to think about it. Tie robot identity to the thing which is physically being controlled and needs considered as a result.

RIO MAC, RIO Serial number, and RIO comment are all tied to the RIO… which has a high probability of correlating to physical mechanism hardware, but is only one frantic electrical swap away from not being corresponded.

An external jumper (with an adorable tether tied to the physical frame) is a good option, but you need to mitigate the chances that it’s either (A) plugged into the wrong spot or (B) not plugged in at all.

An analog port with a resistor divider (like steve said) allows you to differentiate “jumper A”, “jumper B”, and “no jumper”.

A jumper in port 0 is still subject to the “in-range failure” of forgetting to plug it in.

Finally, assuming you can detect “not sure who I am” failures, the question is what to do with it. Reset indefinitely is annoying but safe. Even better, have a way to annunciate software-detected faults by blinking some LED’s annoyingly… maybe even a little text display to say the error. Do this judiciously, pit crew will learn to check the light and trust that if the display says “broken”, there’s actually something to fix.

However, if they get used to “oh yea, that light is always on, ignore it”, it’s pretty much useless.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T22:16:03.199Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":23.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485278,"topic_slug":"2-robots-1-code","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/2-robots-1-code/485278/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503555,"name":"Jake Gads","username":"gadzygadz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gadzygadz/{size}/200701_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T23:38:04.543Z","cooked":"

Depending on the complexity of the differences (for my case it was just zero values of my swerve drive) I placed a file on the testbot called “isTestBot” and then checked for it in my config class. I would then use a trinary assignment to assign values to either the test bot or the real bot

public class Constants {
  public static final boolean isTestBot = Files.exists(Paths.get("/home/lvuser/deploy/isTestBot"));
  ...
  public static final Rotation2d angleOffset = Rotation2d.fromRotations(
      isTestBot ? 0.26171875 : -0.092529
   );
}

I should add this might not be the most the correct way. I took two days off and came back to a second robot being half made and had to adapt.

We have a little pragma that

  • Checks to see if there’s a “which robot am i” in a season specific slot
  • Uses that key if available
  • If missing, sets it to comp bot.
    And you can also bulletproof your spares by further checking to see if it’s connected to the FMS; If so, you can reasonably assert that it’s definitely on comp bot.
